target_title: Don't use C sources to bootstrap vala anymore

target_title: Don't use C sources to bootstrap vala anymore

note.body:
One way would be to
1. make sure the old vala sdk is installed
2. download the new valac sources into a directory
3. run flatpak builder for the manifest with the new vala sdk
   - install only for compile time a script that runs valac outside the sandbox in the other older vala sdk
   - generate the release (C) sources from the downloaded vala sources (2.) with the valac from the other sdk
   - compile and install these sources (for bootstrapping, then again download and compile the latest valac as a normal flatpak module without any external dependencies)

Trailing commas in function calls

note.body:
For visualization this is what I meant:

```vala
foo ({
    "a",
    "b",
    "c",
});
```
instead of 
```vala
foo (
    "a",
    "b",
    "c",
)
```
the first has many advantages over the second:
- support in other language bindings
- more clear (remember var args can start only after some other non-varargs parameters, also they are not structured/typed at all)

target_title: Trailing commas in function calls

note.body: Yes, this is mostly important for varargs, but it seems confusing to special case that

target_title: Trailing commas in function calls

note.body:
But also, I think that too many parameters of one function, even more so if many of them are optional parameters, is a very strong sign of bad design. Usually this happens when you put more and more features into a code base that wasn't prepared for it. For example the gir parser in Vala is a very good example of this. The proper solution is not to make having a lot of parameters more convenient, but to redesign the whole thing, in the gir parser case to be more object oriented (I think thats always the solution) Because then you can make all the parameters properties in a class and make the function a method of that class. solved!

And if you think from that angle and assume that a function shouldn't have too many parameters, adding a feature just for that very rare case seems like not worth it (I would even say it is against valas design goals)

This is also about optional and variable arg parameters (that I wouldn't recommend to use in most cases anyways, an array in a parameter is usually better)

About arrays having this feature I think a new issue could be opened (if it is not implemented yet, actually not sure) so this issue could be close.

target_title: Trailing commas in function calls

note.body:
Here is my view:

1. This is only a convenience feature for git. Having clean diffs is important and not needing to add a comma later just to add a line helps a lot with that. It might be also more convenient in general when writing code, but I wouldn't prioritize that here. I think its more important how the syntax looks than someone needing to type one character less once in a while.

2. I think in other languages this makes a lot more sense because you can add an arbitrary number of parameters later, basically dynamic languages. In Vala this usually is not the case. You define the parameters in the function declaration, and then you will always need all these parameters. And when you change the parameters of a function, that is refactoring, and refactoring is always messy.

3. Optional and variable arg parameters are an exception to this, I would continue the discussion only focusing on them. (If it is even possible to differentiate between them in the parser...?)

4. Also what about arrays? (`{a, b, c, }`) there it seems like a useful feature.

target_title: Trailing commas in function calls

note.body: I will add another voice in favor. In other languages, I always add a trailing comma to multi-line function calls

target_title: vala 0.56.17 tests: error: potential null pointer dereference [-Werror=null-dereference]

note.body: I think the issue can be found by debugging the failed test cases.

target_title: vala 0.56.17 tests: error: potential null pointer dereference [-Werror=null-dereference]

note.body:
tests passes with `-O1`, but not `-Os`, meaning that it is one of the `-O2` options (except those omitted by -Os) that triggers it.

https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc-14.2.0/gcc/Optimize-Options.html

If I set all those flags specified in GCC manual listed for `-O1` and `-O2`, it passes. So it is something else weird that gcc does.

Other quick fix is doing `make -C tests check CFLAGS=""`.

I just want be sure that we don't end up with broken code with our CFLAGS in vala apps.

target_title: vala 0.56.17 tests: error: potential null pointer dereference [-Werror=null-dereference]

note.body: I guess removing that would be a quick fix. But thats not really solution. There is probably some code that expects always aligned memory or something like that.

target_title: vala 0.56.17 tests: error: potential null pointer dereference [-Werror=null-dereference]

note.body: It is `-Os` that does the difference.

target_title: vala 0.56.17 tests: error: potential null pointer dereference [-Werror=null-dereference]

note.body:
on x86_64
```sh
CFLAGS="-Os -fstack-clash-protection -Wformat -Werror=format-security -fno-plt -g"
CXXFLAGS="-Os -fstack-clash-protection -Wformat -Werror=format-security -D_GLIBCXX_ASSERTIONS=1 -D_LIBCPP_ENABLE_THREAD_SAFETY_ANNOTATIONS=1 -D_LIBCPP_ENABLE_HARDENED_MODE=1 -fno-plt -g"
```

on aarch64:
```sh
CFLAGS="-Os -fstack-clash-protection -Wformat -Werror=format-security -g"                                       
CXXFLAGS="-Os -fstack-clash-protection -Wformat -Werror=format-security -D_GLIBCXX_ASSERTIONS=1 -D_LIBCPP_ENABLE
_THREAD_SAFETY_ANNOTATIONS=1 -D_LIBCPP_ENABLE_HARDENED_MODE=1 -g"
```

I think only `CFLAGS` is relevant.

Draft: dbus: Bind properties with the GDBus directly

note.body:
> I think we can use `Array<Type>`. Is it a right way? It doesn't produce notify if we modify it's data.

In theory you can have anything as a property type, the question is if you really want that. And arbitrary arrays you usually really don't want, because first as you mentioned it doesn't emit change notifications, and also user code could freely mess around with the content of the array, because it is writable. Usually what you want is either a `ListModel` or unowned pointer to a C array (in C terms), as they are readonly. For modifying them you would have custom logic/methods.

But I am not so sure about this case, because usually you wouldn't expose the dbus object anyways in a library for example, right?

In C (gdbus-codegen) basically everything thats not a simple type is a gvariant. I guess thats also the current state in vala, right?

Also, one thing I haven't understood yet, how are structs handled? Afai read you can always nest also in arrays as much structs as you want.
